Problem:
Consider a function \( z(t) = e^{j\omega t} x(t) \) where \( x(t) \) is a time-dependent input signal and \( \omega \) is a constant frequency. The dynamics of \( x(t) \) in the system are described by a complex function \( x(t+1) = L x(t) \), where \( L \) is a linear transformation.

If the transformation \( z(t) \) is applied to the signal \( x_0 \) at \( t = 0 \) and then allowed to evolve according to \( x(t+1) = L x(t) \) without further intervention, will \( z(t) \) at \( t = T \) be the same as if \( x_0 \) was directly evolved to \( t = T \) under \( x(t+1) = L x(t) \)?
Explanation: The initial transformation \( z(t) = e^{j\omega t} x(t) \) introduces a complex exponential modulation to the signal, which changes its phase and potentially its amplitude, depending on \( \omega \). This alteration affects the signal’s evolution under \( L \), leading to a different result at time \( T \).
